displaytitle: Ḵaa shaksayéigu (comb) with xóots (bear) and spirit figure
markings: 5056 written on flip side in black ink (conservation request to have it removed).

titles.title: Ḵaa shaksayéigu (comb) with xóots (bear) and spirit figure

texts.textentryhtml: Owned by Chief Yen-aht-setl of Yakutat; Collected by Prof. William Libbey during Mount St. Elias Expedition in 1886; Given to E. M. Museum (Princeton Museum of Natural History), 1886

In 1886, William Libbey, the former director of the University’s now defunct E. M. Museum of Geology and Archaeology, collected this heirloom comb in Yukutat, from Chief Yen-aht-setl. Elaborately carved wooden combs of this sort were worn as adornments, often by shamans, although the history of this object suggests that other members of Yakutat society also used them. The comb depicts the head of an animal, probably a bear, with a small figure perched between the ears, representing a spirit. The back of the comb is carved simply to indicate the creature’s body, with an inverted face where the tail is turned up.
texts.remarks: 2015 AAA Reinstallation WC7 Native North America
